metadata.title: Bell 407
aws::graph::propositions: Bell 407 Helicopter Specifications and History
The Bell 407 features a four-blade main rotor developed for the OH-58D (Model 406).
The Bell 407's rotor blades use composite construction without life limits.
The Bell 407's rotor hub uses composite construction without life limits.
The Bell 407's rotor blades and hub provide better performance than previous models.
The Bell 407's rotor blades and hub provide a more comfortable ride than previous models.
The Bell 407's fuselage is 8 inches (20 cm) wider than previous models.
The Bell 407's wider fuselage increases internal cabin space.
The Bell 407 includes 35% larger main cabin windows.
The Bell 407 uses a Rolls-Royce/Allison 250-C47 turboshaft engine.
The Rolls-Royce/Allison 250-C47 turboshaft is more powerful than previous engines.
The Rolls-Royce/Allison 250-C47 turboshaft allows an increase in Maximum Takeoff Weight.
The Rolls-Royce/Allison 250-C47 turboshaft improves performance at hotter temperatures.
The Rolls-Royce/Allison 250-C47 turboshaft improves performance at higher altitudes.
The Bell 407 has standard seating for two crew members.
The Bell 407 has standard seating for five cabin passengers.
Transport Canada certificated the Bell 407 on February 9, 1996.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) certificated the Bell 407 on February 23, 1996.
Full production of the Bell 407 began in 1996.
The Bell 407 was produced at Bell's Mirabel plant.
Bell's Mirabel plant is located in Quebec, Canada.
Bell produced 140 Bell 407 airframes in 1997.
The 140 Bell 407 airframes produced in 1997 were to fill initial orders.

text:
The Bell 407 features the four-blade main rotor developed for the OH-58D (Model 406). The blades and hub use composite construction without life limits, and provide better performance and a more comfortable ride. The 407's fuselage is 8 inches (20 cm) wider, increasing internal cabin space, and includes 35% larger main cabin windows. The more powerful Rolls-Royce/Allison 250-C47 turboshaft allows an increase in Maximum Takeoff Weight and improves performance at hotter temperatures and/or higher altitudes.   The helicopter has standard seating for two crew and five cabin seats.
The 407 was certificated by Transport Canada on February 9, 1996, with the FAA following shortly after on February 23.  Full production began in 1996 at Bell's Mirabel, Quebec, Canada plant and produced 140 airframes in 1997, to fill the initial orders.
